item.title: 全球最先进的芯片生产商台积电即将在日本开设第一家制造工厂。本月早些时候，它宣布了在附近建立第二家工厂的计划。这与这家台湾巨头在美国陷入困境的扩张形成了鲜明对比： 👇
item.description:
The world’s most advanced chip producer, TSMC, is about to open its first fabrication plant in Japan. Earlier this month it announced plans for a second plant nearby. That contrasts with the Taiwanese giant’s troubled expansion in America: https://t.co/RsttqqbPxp 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 在一些人看来，澳大利亚的野马是牧场文化的最后遗存，这种文化在高原地区受到保护时就已灭绝。但是，随着野马数量的增长，政客们开始打击野马。
item.description:
To some, Australia’s brumbies are a last vestige of a ranching culture extirpated when the high country was protected. But as their population grows, politicians are cracking down on the wild horses https://t.co/TTKNs2wd2g

Photo: Getty Images pic.twitter.com/wPl0iv9QXF

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 对于美国大法官来说，棘手的问题是如何理解社交媒体公司的概念。它们是否类似于报纸，可以完全控制其版面上出现的内容？还是更接近于电话公司或快递服务公司？ 👇
item.description:
The tricky question for America’s justices is how to conceptualise social-media companies.

Are they akin to newspapers, which have total control over what appears in their pages? Or are they closer to phone companies or delivery services? https://t.co/9DDU6cTGpk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 唐纳德-特朗普威胁要将他在 2018 年挑起的贸易战升级，对中国商品征收 60% 或更高的关税。这会对中国企业造成多大伤害？ 👇

item.title: 随着弗拉基米尔-普京发出威胁，唐纳德-特朗普酝酿撤回对欧洲的支持，所有人都认为欧洲需要在武装力量上投入更多资金。但人们较少认识到，这种转变将带来多大的冲击。
item.description:
With Vladimir Putin issuing threats and Donald Trump musing about withdrawing support, everyone agrees that Europe needs to spend more on its armed forces.

What is less widely recognised is how wrenching the shift will be https://t.co/zThYY2TIrP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 日本和美国政府都迫切希望扩大国内芯片生产，并寻求外国公司的帮助。那么，熊本的庆祝与亚利桑那州的头痛形成鲜明对比的原因是什么呢？ 👇
item.description:
Both the Japanese and American governments are eager to expand domestic production of chips, and are seeking the help of foreign firms. So what explains the contrast between celebrations in Kumamoto and headaches in Arizona? https://t.co/GX3jrwJGNl 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 许多人在离开大学时都背负着沉重的债务，获得的学位也只是一个无关紧要的、教学质量很差的学位。他们被骗了，没有为更好的生活做好准备👇。
item.description:
Many leave university loaded with debt and equipped with a degree of peripheral relevance that has been taught badly. They are being ripped off, not prepared for a better life https://t.co/n61F6MOJCE 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 腐败是问题的核心。监狱工作人员敲诈勒索盛行，贿赂可以买到更好的牢房。1843 》杂志探究了俄罗斯刑事系统的内部运作。
item.description:
Corruption lies at the heart of it. Racketeering by prison staff is endemic and bribery can buy you a better cell. But those who refuse to pay get “broken”—beaten or tortured.

1843 magazine explores the inner workings of Russia’s penal system https://t.co/cmLDFHeWQk

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: "监狱系统的目标......是打垮人们，摧毁他们的人格，为民众接种反自由的疫苗。"俄罗斯最受瞩目的政治犯之一向《1843》杂志提供了古拉格集中营生活的独特见解
item.description:
“The goal of the penitentiary system…is to break people, to destroy their personality and to vaccinate the population against freedom.”

One of Russia’s highest-profile political prisoners gives 1843 magazine a unique insight into life inside a gulag https://t.co/XFeSOgTwkR

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 林赛-霍伊尔爵士对国会议员福祉的关注使他在议会中异常受欢迎。但这并没有提高英国人对政治家的信任--现在，这已经危及到他的职业生涯 ⬇️。
item.description:
